lg.l: My Dear Countrymen;

──────────Mediocribus esse Poetis,
Non funes, non Gryps, non concessere columnæ.
TO give you a short translation of these 2 Lines from Horace's Art of Poetry, which I have chosen for my Neck-verse, before I proceed to my Speech, you will find they fall Naturally into this Sense.

────For Poets, who can tell Rocks from Stones,
The Rope, the Hangman, and the Gallows groans.

I was born in a Fen near the Foot of Mount Parnassus, commonly call'd the Log-wood Bog; my Mother whose Name was Stanza, conceiv'd me in a Dream, and was deliver'd of me in her sleep, Her Dream was that Apollo in the Shape of a Gander, with a prodigious long Bill had embrac'd her, Upon which she consulted the Oracle of Delphos; and the following Answer was given.
You'l have a Gosling call it Dan
And doe not make your Goose a Swan,
'Tis true because the God of Wit
To get him in that Shape thought fit,
He'l have some Glow-worm Sparks of it,
Venture you may to turn him loose,
But let it be t'another Goose.
The time will come, the fatal time
When he shall dare a Swan to Rhyme,
The Tow'ring Swan comes sowsing down
And breaks his Pinions, cracks his Crown,
From that sad time, and sad Disaster,
He'l be a lame crack'd Poetaster.
At length for stealing Rhymes, and Triplets,
He'l be condemn'd to hang in Giblets.

You see now Gentlemen this is fatally and litterally come to pass, for it was my Misfortune to engage with that Pindar of the Times W────m D────n who did so confound me by sowsing on my Crown and did so batter my Pinions, that I was forc'd to make use of borrow'd Wings, tho' my false Accusers have depos'd, that I stole my Feathers from Hopkins, Sternhold, Silvestre, Ogilby, Durffy, &c. for which I now forgive 'em and all the World, I dye a Poet, and this Ladder shall be my Gradus ad Parnassum, and I hope the Criticks will have Mercy on my Works,
Then lo! I mount as slowly as I sung,
And then I'l make a Line for ev'ry rung.
There's Nine I see──── the Muses too are Nine,
Who would refuse to dye a Death like mine?
1 Thou first Rung Clio, celebrate my Name,
2 Euterp, in Tragick Numbers doe the Same,
3 This rung I see Terpsichore's thy Flute
4 Erato sing me to the God's,──── ah do't,
5 Thalia, dont make me a Comedy,
6 Urania, raise me towards the Starry Skie.
7 Calliope, to ballad strains descend 3}
8 And Polhymnia, tune 'em for your Friend,
9 So shall Melpom'ne mourn my fatal end,
ADVERTISEMENT.

I Publish this Speech at the request of my Friends in order to prevent the Sons of Grubstreet from telling Lyes, after my Death and as it is very probable there will some stories be publish'd I intreat the World to listen to None of 'em, being false and Scandalous, having nothing else to say, I bequeath my Crutches to the hangman together with my two Legg'd Wig which may serve instead of a Rope, when he undergoes this Punishment which will not be Long e'er it happen, I dye of the Brethren of Sycamore-Alley, and am about two and forty Years of Age, and the Lord have Mercy on My Soul Amen.
|||||||||Copia Vera.
